Posts.EditableText:
I would guess that the room description is not picking up the drawer. One way to do this would be to have the desk as a container that can be opened as closed, and the phone in the desk.

If you want it specifically in a drawer, I would put the drawer in the room, not in the desk. That way the room description will find the drawer, see it is a container, and so find the contents. You might want to mark the drawer as scenery; I think it will then only get listed after opening, but you may want to play around and see.

I've been creating various containers today, up to five items nested.
The desk and drawer is pretty straightforward.

Add object(desk) to room.
Select - Container.
Check - Open
Check - Hide until..
Check - List children...

Add object(drawer) to desk.
Select - Closed container.
Check - Can be opened.
Check - Can be Closed.
Check - List children.

Add object(mobile) to drawer.

All three items should be unchecked in set-up tab 'scenery' option.

Doing it this way, you will, of course, lose the 'surface' option for displaying desktop objects, the addition of a small table or filing cabinet to the room could remedy this.
